Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story: The snow was coming down harder than I’d seen all winter, swirling in thick sheets across the windshield. My phone buzzed on the dashboard—another message from my brother, reminding me not to be late for Mom’s birthday dinner. I could almost hear his voice, “You promised you’d be there this time.” I wanted to be. I wanted to sit at the table, laugh, and watch Mom blow out her candles. But in the back seat, my passenger was checking his watch every few seconds, anxiety etched across his face. He had a flight to catch, and the airport was still miles away, traffic crawling at a snail’s pace. As a taxi driver, I was supposed to get him there safely and on time, no matter the weather. My hands gripped the wheel tighter, heart pounding with the weight of both promises. I could feel the pull from both sides—my family waiting, my passenger depending on me. The clock ticked on, and I was caught in the middle, torn between being the sister they needed and the driver he counted on.
